Situation1: Early in their career, they have not yet saved enough for travel.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. The notification blinked: “Legislative aide available for call—10 minutes only.” This was the moment I’d been working toward for months, the chance to push for the policy change I believed in. But as I reached for my notes, my mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me that the Hajj registration deadline was today. I hadn’t saved enough yet, but she insisted I at least begin the process, to show my intention and commitment as a Muslim. The expectation weighed on me—fulfilling this pillar of faith, even if it meant stretching myself thin. Yet, the activist in me knew how rare this opportunity was; missing the call could set our campaign back. My hands trembled as I glanced between the Hajj website and my phone, feeling the pressure of two worlds colliding, each demanding my full attention, each representing a part of who I am.
